data.title: A Classic Downtown Dining Experience
data.text: The Temple is semi-regular lunch venue.  Kind of a step back in time with a varied menu and great prices.  The staff is very helpful and friendly.  I've ordered different items from the menu and they've all been really good.  My favorite is the taco salad.  Very clean, good portions, great value.

data.title: The BEST downtown lunch spot
data.text: My partner and I love eating here for lunch. The meals are moderately priced and you get what you pay for. Its always a positive experience here....with the food and waitstaff.

data.title: Always a good home-cooked meal!
data.text: This place has a rich history in Downtown Flint, the food is excellent, they do catering too, they even did my sit down wedding!

data.title: The Best!
data.text: A real "Flintstone" gem.  My favorite place😍.  Never had a bad meal; started going when I was about 7 years old-- I am silver haired and much older now! Don't pass up the opportunity to eat there!  Like home cooked love.  Even if you are eating alone-service is great.

data.title: FLINT TREASURE
data.text: Family owned and operated brings quality and excellence. Homemade delicious foods. I have eaten here too many times to count and have been coming to eat here for decades. I have never had a bad meal or service. Chicken, steaks, meatloaf, mashed potatoes, just a wonderful variety of terrific food. The staff and kitchen go out of their way to make everyone enjoy the meal. The pies are the best, so save room for dessert!!

data.title: Good food!
data.text: Every time I have been there for various events the food has been first rate.When on jury duty the chicken was good, and the pie tasted home made. While there for a Shriners event, again, great food.

data.title: I love the Masonic Temple Dining Room!
data.text: The food you grew up on! Everything is always delicious. The bean soup is my favorite. The squash is the best I have ever tasted. Great desserts too!

data.title: Great food
data.text: The food and service is amazing.. I love it there because it takes me back in time,,,, along with such delicious food..

data.title: The place for lunch.
data.text: The food is wonderful, the service is fantastic, the prices are reasonable; every restaurant should be like this one. The only drawbacks are parking and hours of operation.

data.title: Homemade food and Sunday Chicken Dinners
data.text: The Masonic Temple dining Room is a downtown lunch time staple.  It is not fancy, but it has an elegant feel with a large dining room.  The service is fast and friendly and the food has a homemade quality.  They are FAMOUS for their homemade pies.  On most Sundays they serve an all you can eat chicken dinner buffet at a very low price and a portion of the proceeds go to local non-profits.   This is a popular hangout for many judges, lawyers and other professionals.

data.title: Amazing value for a terrific salad
data.text: I had an excellent spinach salad that was a generous portion of very fresh greens, egg, bacon and mushrooms.  The price, under $7, was well worth it.  The service is very friendly as well.

data.title: Good food, good shows!
data.text: I like going for lunch and then watching one of their many fine productions.  Usually, I go with my lady friends, all of whom enjoy the experience.  Great chicken lunch or dinner!

data.title: Best Lunch in Downtown Flint
data.text: They may only be open for lunch a few hours each day M-F and only in the winter months but this place is a piece of downtown Flint history.  With it's daily specials and old time favorites you will never leave hungry or broke.  If you can't make it for lunch keep a look out for their chicken charity dinners, always good food for a good cause.

data.title: Dining amongst the dinosaurs... ok, not quite
data.text:
This place is ancient... most definately one of the oldest public dining spots in the area.  If you want a "time machine" experience of how your grandparents dined on their lunch break from work (if they had an office job... that is), this is the place to visit.  Many patrons here look like Miss Daisy, or at least, of her generation.

You enter the Temple Dining room by climbing a flight of granite or marble steps off Saginaw street to the Masonic Temple foyer, then down a flight of marble stairs to the basement level.

Hours of operation are limited to a few around lunchtime, although a few special dates on weekends, they serve all-you-can-eat chicken dinners for fundraisers. 

The food is of a bygone era, yet good enough to try every once in a while.  The prices are reasonable, and nothing costs more than 6 or 7 dollars, tops (lunchtime).   Food is ordered from a menu, and is served to your table (not cafeteria style) at lunchtime.  If you go to an all-you-can-eat chicken fundraiser dinner, then the food IS served cafeteria-buffet style.

The dining room tables and chairs are ancient, and are showing some wear, although they are extremely well constructed, and seem to be holding up well.  Cloth tablecloths with paper placemats and stainless steel tableware are the fashion.  The chairs are upholstered with heavy duty Naugahyde, or something similar, with many, many tacks at the edges (you just don't see these used anymore).  The beams at the ceiling are covered with 1970s dark paneling, and there are asbestos wrapped pipes here and there in the corridor.

You pay as you leave at a cahier's desk (see photo).  

If you want to venture into the world of nostalgia, come on in.
